children.text:
The program reads a number as a string, processes its digits from least to most significant, and calculates some bills based on each digit's value. The main steps are:

1. Read the input number.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: 2. Convert each character of the string to digits, reversing them (since the first character is the least significant digit).
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: 3. Process each digit to compute the bills, considering carry-over when digits exceed certain values.
children.label: high_level_plan

program atcoder_abc155_e
implicit none

integer :: num_length
character(len=100000) :: number
integer, dimension(:), allocatable :: digits
integer :: i, pos
integer :: bills

! Read input
read(*, '(A)') number
num_length = len_trim(number)

!
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Allocate digits array from 0 to num_length (size num_length+1)
allocate(digits(0:num_length))

! Initialize digits to 0
digits = 0

! Fill the digits with reversed digits
do i =0, num_length-1
    pos = num_length -i 
    digits(i) = ichar(number(pos:pos)) - ichar('0')
end do

! Now process each digit for bills
bills =0

do i =0, num_length
    if (digits(i) ==10 ) then
        digits(i+1) = digits(i+1)+1
        digits(i) =0
    end if

! Now check the current digit[i] value

    if (digits(i) <5 ) then
        bills = bills + digits(i)
    else if (digits(i) ==5 ) then
        if (digits(i+1) >=5 ) then
            digits(i+1) = digits(i+1)+1
        end if
        bills = bills +5
    else 
        ! digits(i) > =6 
        digits(i+1) = digits(i+1)+1
        bills = bills + (10 - digits(i))
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
end if

end do

write(*,*) bills
end program atcoder_abc155_e

In the Java code, digits[L+1] is accessed when i=L (since L is number.length()), which is the upper bound. Thus the array is so that digits[0...L], so to access digits[L+1], we must have space.

Therefore, in Fortran, the digits array must be of size 0...L+1. So, need:

allocate( digits(0: num_length +1) )

then in the loop, i can go up to num_length → so digits(i+1) will go to num_length+1 which is within the array.

So the code needs to adjust the allocation and array limits:

Now rework the Fortran code step by step.

Rewriting all:

1) Read the number into a character array. Let's choose a big length, say 100000:

2) num_length is the trimmed length.

3) Allocate digits as (0:num_length+1). So digits can hold the original digits plus one digit.

Then processing steps.

Therefore:

program atcoder_abc155_e
    implicit none
    character(len=100000) :: number
    integer :: num_length, i, pos
    integer, allocatable :: digits(:) 
    integer :: bills

! Read input
    read(*, '(A)') number
    num_length = len_trim(number)

! Allocate digits from 0 to num_length+1 (so including one higher than input length)
    allocate( digits(0: num_length+1) )
    digits = 0

! Fill the digits array from reversed string
    do i=0, num_length-1
        pos = num_length -i 
        digits(i) = ichar( number(pos:pos) ) - ichar('0')
    end do

! Compute the bills
    bills =0

    do i=0, num_length

        if (digits(i) == 10) then
            digits(i+1) = digits(i+1) + 1
            digits(i) = 0
        end if

        if (digits(i) <5 ) then
            bills = bills + digits(i)
        else if (digits(i) ==5 ) then
            if( digits(i+1) >=5 ) then
                digits(i+1) = digits(i+1) +1
            end if
            bills = bills +5
        else
            ! digits(i)>=6
            digits(i+1) = digits(i+1) +1
            bills = bills + 10 - digits(i)
        end if
    end do

    write(*,'(i0)') bills

end program atcoder_abc155_e
